scenario_text.value: Hm... This mural is most fascinating.

Could this be the sky and the clouds? Or no,
perhaps it’s a more fundamental phenomenon.
It kind of looks like the sun.

The sun... Yes, so this is light... Could it
be depicting the creation of the world?

If so, then this mural is likely meant to
show that the two worlds were once one.
The worlds...used to be one?
Look closely at the left-hand mural.

Do you see how humans and Kemonogami are
shown coexisting within the same circle?
Oh yeah!

That must be to show that humans and
Kemonogami once lived in the same world.

You can also see that each one is bound to
another by what looks like a string.

I believe this indicates that humans and
Kemonogami were once complementary beings.
Complementary beings? What do you mean?
That they were two halves of the same soul.

In other words, each one could not exist
without the other.
(Kind of like how Agumon and I feel now.)

(But the world was split into two, and hardly
anyone in our world believes in Kemonogami.)

(Lots of people don’t believe in gods, let
alone anything like Agumon or the others.)

(And when I think how thoroughly they’ve been
forgotten, it’s actually kind of sad.)

Once, the world was one... Humans and
monsters shared a soul...

If such was the harmonious ideal, which half
was responsible for its downfall?

No, that’s hardly worth asking. The human
form is too frail for the power of a god...
Uh, Professor?

Oh, sorry, don’t mind me. I’m afraid I got
caught up in my own speculation.

Unfortunately, I can’t offer any further
interpretation at this point. Let’s move on.

This mural shows that from the dawn of this
world, humans and Kemonogami coexisted.
